Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Dense micro array of atomic spin-polarized detectors for subfemtatesla level resolution of magnetic field gradient

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: The goal of this project is to explore an approach for detection of magnetic field, both magnitude and directionality, with less than 1 femto-Tesla resolution and better than 10 microns location error in a 10 square centimeter form-factor. The proposed approach is based on implementation of a densely packed array of glass micro-scale cells. Each cell is a hundred micron in diameter and is filled with isotopes of rubidium and buffer gasses. Cells are equally spaced on the same substrate, a hundred micron apart, and each cell acts as a highly precise all-optical atomic magnetometer.
Intellectual Merit: This project will investigate the precession of nuclear spins as the measure of magnetic field magnitude and spatial distribution of magnetometers as a measure of magnetic field gradient. Contrary to SQUIDs, the proposed atomic magnetic gradiometer will not require cryogenic cooling and will not have any moving mechanical parts. A high-performance magnetometry can potentially be achieved by measuring the apparent change of the precession frequency of nuclear spins in response to a weak magnetic field.
Broader Impact: Highly sensitive, small size, and easy to use magnetometers can have transformative effects in various areas including biology and biomedical engineering, geology and mineral/oil exploration, as well as surveillance and defense (through wall/underground imaging and target tracking). Small size and convenience offered by the proposed microscale devices can lead to significant advances in brain mapping and enable development of advanced portable brain monitoring devices. The accessibility of such technology for personal use in the form factor of hand-held devices will revolutionize, for example, personal health-care, on-demand diagnostic, and self-monitoring of chronic deceases. The most noticeable contribution will be in the area of biomagnetism, that is, the detection of the weak magnetic fields produced by the human brain, heart, and other organs. This research will advance scientific knowledge in the areas of innovative sensing concepts, signal processing, and system-level implementation. This highly multidisciplinary project will also provide unique educational experience for undergraduate and graduate (including underrepresented) students through team collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored an approach for detection of magnetic field, both magnitude and directionality, demonstrating  less than 1 femta-Tesla resolution and better than 10 microns location error in a 10 square centimeter form-factor. Our approach was based on implementation of a densely packed array of glass micro-scale cells. Each cell was a hundred micron in diameter and was filled with isotopes of rubidium and buffer gasses. Cells were equally spaced on the same substrate, a hundred micron apart, and each cell acted as a highly precise all-optical atomic magnetometer. We explored and succesfully confirmed  a two-part hypothesis: (1) each cell can be designed to preserve its sensitivity to a low magnetic field, less than a pico-tesla, despite its physical size and close proximity of cells in the matrix and (2) the approach allows to reject common parasitic magnetic fields, derive gradient, identify a magnetic dipole, and precisely map the dipole.  

These recent successes demonstrated the feasibility of atomic Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS) and give a reason to explore other types of microdevices where atomic detection mechanisms may be beneficial. This project investigated the precession of nuclear spins as the measure of magnetic field magnitude and spatial distribution of magnetometers as a measure of magnetic field gradient. Contrary to superconducting quantum interference devices (SQUIDs), the demonstrated atomic magnetic gradiometer will not require cryogenic cooling and will not have any moving mechanical parts. A high-performance magnetometry  can  be potentially achieved by measuring the apparent change of the precession frequency of nuclear spins in response to a weak magnetic field. Several challenges were addressed, including the feasibility of operating an atomic magnetometer with a miniature cell and thus a limited number of atoms, magnetic field uniformity in microfabricated coils, effects of assembly and fabrication imperfections, methods for wafer-level filling of alkali metal vapor and noble gases, development of miniature non-magnetic heaters, and the effect of cell shape and buffer gases on the nuclear relaxation time. The atomic micro-magnetometers are envisioned to be integrated on a single substrate, which would minimize  the need for manual assembly.

We demonstrated that the dense array of nuclear-spin-based magnetometers has a potential to exceed the performance of today’s solid-state magnetometers by several orders of magnitude. Today's systems with femtatesla resolution are made out of distributed discrete sensor nodes, and therefore large, bulky, and expensive. Such systems are only available in highly specialized medical facilities, dedicated military constellations, or expensive mobile platforms. The accessibility of such technology for personal use in the form factor of hand-held devices will revolutionize, for example, personal health-care, on-demand diagnostic, and self-monitoring of chronic deceases.  The most noticeable contribution will be in the area of biomagnetism, that is, the detection of the weak magnetic fields produced by the human brain, heart, and other organs. 

This research advanced scientific knowledge in the areas of innovative sensing concepts, signal processing, and system-level implementation.  This highly multidisciplinary project also provided   unique    educational    experience    for  undergraduate  and  graduate students through team collaborations.
